text: hi everyone Anthony fantano here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of this new James
Blake album playing robots into heaven
this is the sixth full-length LP from
producer songwriter singer Mr James
Blake whose style and career are kind of
difficult to sum up because he's got so
much range as a DJ an electronic music
artist an occasional Hip Hop Production
collaborator singer pianist he wears
many hats continues to do it all and has
recently dropped one of the more
difficult to categorize records of the
year now let's rewind back to 2021 when
James came out with his record friends
that break your heart which was pretty
much his most focused album in terms of
flexing his singer-songwriter muscles
really pushing them to their limit in
part so we could end that chapter of his
career for a moment and move on to
something else beats modular synths
Electronics generally pretty much the
name of the game I'm playing robots into
heaven where it seems like James is
giving himself as few artistic
boundaries as possible and just allowing
whatever artistic whim grabs at him to
bring him wherever it wants to go which
has led to a project that is a little
all over the place but there is a slowly
intensifying progression to the madness
the intro asking to break is a chill
tone Setter of sorts a mild Motif with a
laid-back beat Heavenly vocal harmonies
and some chopped up piano passages there
is a serious Stillness to it that just
has me waiting for what's to come there
are some lyrical refrains on the track
too saying true love allows for a break
which I'm not sure whether or not to
take that on face value or maybe
interpret it as an association between
James and music or James and his
audience in terms of there being enough
love there to allow him this chance to
just do something different the
following track loading is a true blue
dance cut but done in a way that is true
to James's style The Groovy and driving
kicks are there for sure but there's
also these glistening synth passages and
what sounds like churchy organs some
pristine gorgeous pitched cherub vocals
too it's a visceral track but it's still
packed with all of those super Regal and
pretty Aesthetics that make James music
what it is much of the time it's like a
remix of one of his songs that don't
exist the dance production then gets
even more explosive on the track tell me
with bigger kicks and some stuttering
synth leads
it's giving 2 A.M Warehouse Rave with
lasers flying in every direction but
also again it's like a remix of a James
Blake song that doesn't exist a good one
but still now of course this song exists
this is the song and it exists I'm just
saying the same beautiful keyboard work
and vocals that you might typically
catch on one of James's ballads turns up
also on these tracks you're just hearing
it in more of a dance context and it
works which is also the case for the
track fall back these Cuts add up into
quite the three track run on the album
and then we hit a switch up with the
song he's been wonderful which is made
up of so many disparate elements you
have these glitchy hits of bass very
sparse and dry beats some gospel piano
and group vocal samples Slinky and
Plucky synth cycles and finally these
persistent counts of one two three one
two three it's such a potpourri of
different sounds that I'm not exactly
sure Works entirely but I'm glad James's
mind goes there and possibly sees more
common ground where most people might
see a clash big hammer is another beat
but with more cohesion this time around
we have some very dry perks and bass
these stuttering robotic synth passages
which are topped with these chopped up
dance hall vocal versus I don't really
mind all these elements as a combo but
the pacing leaves a bit to be desired
the progression is kind of slow and I
wish it varied a bit more as it went
along because I think kind of saturating
the mix with effects didn't really make
for a super strong finish we head back
into house territory with some shuffling
garage rhythms I want you to know but
this time we're getting synths and beats
and production that are so light and
Airy and Blissful it doesn't have a
super strong bite with it at least not
in comparison with other tracks here
though I do think the song comes to a
pretty strong finish with some zigging
and zagging samples and a sort of
chaotic bass breakdown from here James
hits us with a kind of abstract final
leg there's night sky which is kind of
like some super off-kilter beat music
with some heavily treated lead vocals it
sounds like something that would come
out on like a flying lotus's brain
feeder records but on an LSD trip that
sends you through the Pearly Gates it's
fine while it's on but there's not a
whole lot about the track that stuck
with me then fire the editor I think is
the closest James comes on this record
to uh you know getting back into
singer-songwriter mode as the beat is
not super danceable and the vocals are
raw intimate and there's a pretty clear
narrative coming off of them with James
singing about this internal voice this
internal editor creating this sense of
fear around failure or trying something
new trying something different going in
another Direction which obviously uh the
desire to do that the escape from the
conventional is what this record is all
about for him if you can hear me is a
shorter moment on the album kind of
another Motif in an interview I had with
James he talked about how this piece was
originally supposed to be a part of the
soundtrack for the movie Ad Astra though
obviously he ultimately did not end up
involved in the film but I guess he had
these keys and this poem and vocal
passage recorded and done the words very
much reflect on one's connection with
their father it's kind of an odd
addition to the record considering its
origin however it does kind of
effectively bring us mood and Vibe wise
into the Stellar title track The
Finisher which is this beautiful modular
ambient synth piece with a few different
layers going on a lot of atmosphere and
the vibe of this thing I think is
exactly what the title promises robots
slowly marching into heaven it is equal
parts beautiful and Eerie like the best
ambient pieces it puts me in a lull into
a hypnotic state I'm not so much worried
about how long is it lasting how long is
it going to go on
um is is it going to move or progress
into anything beyond this it's a sense
of Stillness it's a sense of place that
I'm just immersed in I want to get lost
in and yeah this piece conjures all that
and more overall I felt this was a very
good album from James even if it's not
one of his most organized there are
quite a few great dance and experimental
cuts on this thing and at the very least
interesting moments that fuse together
multiple elements of James's repertoire
I'm feeling a light to decent seven on
this one transition have you given this
